title: What role did credit play in the 1920s? - Quora

response.answer_text: There was no consumer credit like today whatsoever. However there was a ton of farm credit backed by the farmer’s farm, house and land and crops and livestock. That’s why today a few old banks still use the word Farmers in their names. By the mid 1920’s farms were starting to be foreclosed by the banks. Then the Dust Bowl came into the Midwest and just about forced all farmers into foreclosure. This is one of the key reasons that led to the Great Depression. This was like the mortgage failure of the 2008 -2010 only much worse. These farm foreclosures in the 1920s was like 2008 only on steroids.

In the US, the 1920s were the first period of widely available consumer credit, which fueled the boom in the automobile, radio, and electrical appliance industries. And speculation in the stock market was fueled by the easy availability of credit to buy stock on margin.
